body:
Why not cherry pick the Jena codebase changes for FFFD handling? Then you'd know if 4.3 will work for you; otherwise you will need to revisit this issue.

Whether warning are reported or not is controlled by the `ErrorHandler` of the `TokenizerText`, or you can turn warnings off in the logger. For example, `NodecSSE`.

The Jena changes also include writer handling (JENA-2186) so that Jena does not write raw FFFD. Warnings only happen when data is first ingested.

(The original files mentioned in JENA-2179 were created by TQ tools in the first place.)
In JENA-2197, the whitespace facet fix changed constructor usage to factory method `NodeValueDateTime.create`.

Thanks for the pointers. I did look into some of what you mention:

I started with cherry picking "JENA-2179..."[1]; but it still logged warnings when the `TokenizerText.errorHandler` was built by `RDFParserBuilder` (using `ErrorHandlerFactory.getDefaultErrorHandler()`). We could change the factory default error handler, but that is used in a lot of places and is a bit risky at this point.

And elsewhere: although the warnings are ignored, there was no way to configure `NodecSSE` to pass a different `ErrorHandler` to `TokenizerText`. That is not critical to us; just an observation.

So: We are already in beta and I am trying to reduce the number and complexity of code changes. I would also like to sidestep the need to find all the places our code might trigger these warnings and verify the resultant behavior. So I took the most direct route of removing all the U+FFFD checks in `TokenizerText`. Of course, we will revisit all this post-release; worst case, when we move to Jena 4.3+.

Also, I do not understand the change to the writers to "escape" the U+FFFD. That just seems to be a workaround that stops the warnings in subsequent parsing. Which raises the question: Why were these warnings added to the Jena parsers? U+FFFD is a legal Unicode character; so why the warning? It seems like, by the time it is being read, the cat is out of the bag and there is nothing anyone can do to fix the implied problem (improper encoding/decoding). But maybe I am missing the use case(s)?

Anyway, thanks again for the suggestions.

[1] [394598d70ff4373b7fd335e79d100d8081af7fb0](https://github.com/apache/jena/commit/394598d70ff4373b7fd335e79d100d8081af7fb0)

`NodecSSE` does not print warnings, only errors and fatal.
What other configuration might be used?

[NodecSSE line 136](https://github.com/apache/jena/commit/394598d70ff4373b7fd335e79d100d8081af7fb0#diff-328894f6474e24eac980398f772f09938cbb2190b06a80c94977caf6d9fc8b2cR136)

TDB2 is not affected.

> seems to be a workaround that stops the warnings in subsequent parsing.

Exactly - though it is not a "workaround"; it is intentional. It means that IF
data in Jena has FFFD THEN it is silently round-tripped.

The reason for the change from other users experience working with corrupted
data. The raw FFFD is _not in the original input_, it is generated by the JDK.
The input file was not legal syntax. The FFFD is a translation artifact so that it is a
warning, not a fatal error. \uFFFD means two cases can be distinguished.

The syntax of Turtle allows various bad Unicode string cases (e.g. misused surrogates) and if the input isn't legal UTF-8 then it's not legal because Turtle is defined for UTF-8.  So, like IRIs, the Turtle (etc) grammar isn't the end of the story.

The files you are dealing with were written by TopQuadrant tools in the first place, and stored in TopQuadrant source control.
for Jena.

There aren't many places in TBS where the parser is called.

This needs fixing. Builds work ... if an existing jena-querybuilder snapshot build from a previous run (local copy) or is reachable (maybe by pulling from the Apache development repo). So this would bite during the release process - glad you have found it now not later!
These pages were a quick hack, for local use, that escaped into the wild. There shouldn't be any appearance-related HTML in the validators output!

Hi @kinow

This is what I tried:

Pulled the PR and did "mvn install" . Unpacked the `apache-jena-fuseki` zip and run `java -jar fuseki-server.jar`.

I get new appearance but the UI does not seem to be able to talk to the server. The server status is always red, and creating a dataset fails.

There doesn't seem to be a "run" directory. What have I missed?

Hi @afs 

That's good progress I guess. Last I worked on the branch, I wasn't sure how to package the new UI with the old Servlets project. Looks like the build is at least working partially. I also got the new UI, but it's not pointing to the right backend URL. I'm taking a look and trying to get it to work building with `mvn install` and using the ZIP as you did :+1:

Hmm, running `FusekiCmd` in Eclipse it works fine.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/304786/143190685-e8f79acf-3b48-497e-b442-2bbf8b665316.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/304786/143190710-6eac5c1c-3538-4617-a5ad-290aed6a8a8e.png)

So it must be something with how I tried to glue the Vue UI in the Fuseki war/jar.

Found it @afs. I had a `webapp` folder in the ZIP file (which is searched/used first by the command if it contains a `web.xml`).

However, the webapp folder had the contents of the new UI only. `jena-fuseki-webapp` has `jena-fuseki-ui` as dependency, and has a `web.xml` plus copies the `jena-fuseki-ui` new files as well.

So the solution is the last commit, where I copied the webapp generated by `jena-fuseki-webapp` into the assembly output. It should work now @afs :crossed_fingers: If that works, you can try resizing the browser window, or using a mobile. If I recall correctly, I did a few adjustments in the CSS/HTML to support responsive UI in most screens.

-Bruno
Fixed code based on @rvesse 's feedback (thanks) and tested the zip again after a `mvn clean install -Pdev`. Tests passing, UI working OK, and successfully created a dataset.

Looks great! I got it work with Fuseki Main (via https://github.com/afs/fuseki-mod-ui) serving the files from the classpath by copying to src/main/resources/vue and serving that from the classpath with Jetty static assets servlet.

1. What source is copied from other open source projects that will end up? (For the LICENSE / NOTICE files)
1. As it depends on no Jena artifacts, can we move the build to just after `jena-fuseki-access`? This makes it "one of the modules" and can then go into Fuseki Mian as easily as Fuseki webapp.
1. How easy is to to provide a version with no "manage" version?
1. Formatting of results - can have have "" on strings and _: for bnode labels (I realise this is about yasgui/yasr)

About 3: if the files can be served from the classpath, then Fuseki Main can have query/data load without a fixed directory structure on the server side because all the configuration is from the command line (or an assembler file on the command line).
The on-disk state is one of the complicated bits of the original webapp.

Every time I going to the query tab it seems quite slow (but my machine may not be setup correctly having flipped UI implementations and general have a polluted browser).

Hi,

So this is not a Java webapp (WAR packaging)? Because in a WAR static files
(.js, .css etc.) should go into ‘webapp’, not ‘resources’.

Maybe a follow-up issue. I think the development in yasgui/yasr is slow/stopped. But being JS, we can try to tap into the yasgui/yasr objects when loading the JS app, and change a little bit how they behave.

So in other words, we can have fixes for bugs in yasgui/yasr in Fuseki UI. Then we submit pull requests there and wait until merged, and remove our patched code once it's done.

BTW, if anyone would like to try changing the Fuseki UI code, just start `FusekiServer` either from jar or Eclipse. The important part is to have `localhost:3030` serving Fuseki.

Then start the UI in development mode. By going to `fuseki2/jena-fuseki-ui` directory, installing dependencies with `yarn install`, and start the dev server with `yarn run serve`.

Now change the code as much as you like. The `run serve` command starts a dev server that monitors for changes in the source code (styles, JS, HTML/templates, etc), and re-starts the dev server in ms/seconds.

The dev server will be available in `http://localhost:8080` (important, not 3030, but 8080). It has a `devServer` proxy (see the `fuseki-ui` configuration files in the root) which proxies requests to `:8080/$/ping` to `:3030/$/ping` (hence the requirement to have Fuseki Server listening 3030 in development).

The port number shouldn't matter in production or when the UI is packaged.

- load the value dynamically from something like a Servlet in Fuseki that reads from disk, from a dataset, or from some other service, etc

After we have it merged, my plans are:

- [ ] write unit and end-to-end tests to cover most basic functionality (formatting a query, submitting a query, clicking on the menu to navigate the site, etc)
- [ ] move the common code (i.e. not specific to vue) to JS or TypeScript code. So that we can always use this code, no matter the framework (I migrated a lot of old JS code that was in the middle of Backbone.js code; now this code is in the middle of some Vue code/components; IMHO moving it into a separate place will make maintenance and future upgrades like this a lot smoother)

Minor news item: I've prototyped the admin functions (create, delete at `/$/datasets` and backups) as a Fuseki Module for Fuseki Main and secured them for localhost only.

Fuskei Main does not have Shiro (it can work with Shiro; for users/password it uses Jetty authentication).

For securing admin generally, we know localhost only is inconvenient at times. I would still not like "open" as the default. I'm wondering about command line arg: `--admin=FILE` where FILE is JSON `{ user: "", password: ""}` (so the password isn't on the command line and viewable with process viewing tools) which would allow it from anywhere.  Maybe a special `--admin=*` for explicitly no user/password for quick-convenience. At least then it is an explicit step by the user.

Don't believe you can add it to the start of the arguments because that is a Shell feature and a process invoked via `ProcessBuilder` is not being invoked via a Shell (unless you specifically build that)

Note that I believe @afs added this `export` already to the `xloader` scripts that invoke these commands so this PR may be unnecessary

Thank you @rvesse, I see it is set it is set in the xloader-index. I did see some speed improvements on a test-run, so I assumed the locale wasn't set. I'll double check  and see if it is already set and then close the PR.

The PR looks good to me -- it uses `ProcessBuilder.environment` to set the environment of the subprocess.

`xload-index` isn't part of `tdb2.xloader` - it's the TDB1 xloader (tdbloader2 revised) which I haven't been keeping in step. `tdbr.xloader0` is that setup for TDB2.

With processes being setup and called from Java there is less reason to have the old multi-script setup. There is even a development-support java command line `CmdxLoader` which runs TDB2.xloader without shell. I did find that exiting JVMs after heavy use when swapping to a new step in the process helped probably because it reset OS predictions (need to revisit sometime).

I'm not sure whether it is worth supporting TDB1 as well. There is a lot of practice and experience to gain for running ans supporting large scale loads so having a focus on TDB2 not get too spread out seems sensible.

Out of curiosity - why is the first call to Jena at `RDFWriterRegistry`?

It is safer to explicitly call `JenaSystem.init` from the application before any Jena calls. This is the most tested and reliable approach. Ordering of Java class initialization gets pretty complicated quite quickly.

@afs most of the feedback addressed, with one question about the menu navigation.

I separated in commits, so we can revert or modify any of the changes (or if you'd like to take a look at what was required to change each one; I find it easier than with the old Bootstrap JS code, although it does require some understanding of Vue/JS.)

Oh, also found a nasty bug. I was using the array index as `:key` in Vue. Vue has the concept of `data` in a component. The `Menu` component will have a `data` section, which belongs to the component (you can pass variables as `props` that are accessible in `this.prop` or `this.data`, anyhoo).

When you want to display multiple items, you do something like

`<div v-for"item in someList" :key="item.id">`.

But I used the array index, which is a bad practice. In the end, deleting datasets too quickly could accidentally delete the wrong dataset :disappointed_relieved: :open_mouth: 

But it's fixed, and I couldn't find any other instance of that. So one possible bug fixed. I thought it would take longer, but since I finished everything in one day, I might still have time this week to start writing some tests to prevent any other possible bugs (inherited from the old code, or introduced by yours truly :)
